did.abstract: Robert William Hall was a professor of analytical chemistry at New York University from 1888-1904. Hall also served as treasurer of NYU’s Athletic Association, founding member and Chairman of the University’s Summer School Program (1895-1904), Reader of Chemistry for the College Entrance Examination Board (ca. 1902-1903), and as a member of the Chemical Club. His collection consists of seven notebook pages of lecture notes for his course on quantitative chemical analysis. Hall's notes contain no date; however, he likely composed them between 1896 and 1904 (an assumption based on Hall's using the new name for the institution--New York University--as opposed to the University of the City of New York).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Robert William Hall's collection consists of seven notebook pages of lecture notes for his course on quantitative chemical analysis. Hall's notes contain no date; however, he likely composed them between 1896 and 1904 (an assumption based on Hall's using the new name for the institution--New York University--as opposed to the University of the City of New York). Students enrolled in Hall's course devoted their efforts to accurate weighing (on the rough chemical balance, the analytical balance, and actual weighing) and measuring, by calibrating sets of weights, burettes, flasks, and pipettes, as delineated by his notes. Hall's course also entailed typical exercises in volumetric and gravimetric work, and lectures on the technique and theory of quantitative analysis.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials at the NYU Archives
relatedmaterial.p: Robert William Hall served as a founding member and Chairman (1896-1904) of the University Summer School Program, established in 1895. Researchers should consult the Records of the University Summer School (1895-1909), RG 16.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Professor Hall's notes exist in the order in which he composed them and are housed in one legal-sized folder.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Robert William Hall was born in Armagh, Ireland, on April 25, 1853. He graduated from Princeton University in 1873 with an A.B., and then from Columbia University's School of Mines (subsequently the Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science) in 1876, obtaining the degrees of M.A. and M.E. From 1879 to 1888, he served as manufacturing chemist to the American Gas Fuel and Light Company and to some associated companies. Hall entered NYU (then the University of the City of New York) during the fall of 1888 as Acting Assistant Professor of General Chemistry. In the autumn of 1890, Hall became Professor of Analytical Chemistry and served as both the Chemistry and Analytical Chemistry department chairs during the 1890-1891 academic year. Professor Morris Loeb assumed the Chemistry chairmanship in the fall of 1891, and Professor Hall remained the Analytical Chemistry chair thereafter. Hall began teaching quantitative chemical analysis (the subject of his lecture notes) in the fall of 1892 at the University’s Old Main Building in Washington Sqaure; he moved uptown with the University’s Chemistry Laboratory at the newly opened University Heights Campus in 1894. Professor Hall also served as Treasurer of NYU’s Athletic Association, founding member and Chairman of the University’s Summer School Program (1895-1904), Reader of Chemistry for the College Entrance Examination Board (ca. 1902-1903), and as a member of the Chemical Club. Hall resigned from his professorship at NYU in 1904.
